bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thurman B. Rice, February 10, 1948

div1.p: Hench introduces himself to Rice and discusses his planned book on the conquest of yellow fever. Hench wishes to purchase a copy of Rice's biography of J.W. Hurty because there is a photograph of the room in which Reed presented his paper, in 1900. He inquires if Rice knows where Reed stayed in Indianapolis for the 1900 conference.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thurman B. Rice, February 10, 1948
div1.opener:
February 10, 1948
Dr. Thurman B. Rice
3167 North Delaware
Indianapolis, Indiana
My dear Doctor Rice:
div1.p:
I am writing a book on the conquest of yellow fever and in this
connection have visited Cuba 3 times and most of the survivors of Walter
Reed and his colleagues. By separate post I am sending you a reprint on
the subject.

The details concerning Reed's presentation of the preliminary
note in Indianapolis in October 1900, have not appeared in any publication
to my knowledge. From time to time, I tried to get some information from
public libraries in Indianapolis and did get photostatic copies of the
newspapers of the day after Reed's talk but I was unable to find much.

Recently my friend, Hal Keeling, who has been a patient at the
Clinic from time to time, was here and I enlisted his help. He and his
colleague, Mr. Ray Sweeney, have given me much help indeed. Especially
did they call my attention to your interesting book, “The Hoosier Health
Officer, a Biography of Dr. J. N. Hurty, a History of the Indiana State
Board of Health to 1925”. Mr. Keeling was able to borrow this book for
me briefly but I had to return it almost immediately. Could you tell me
if there is a possibility that I could purchase this volume somewhere?
I notice that these articles also ran serially in the bulletin of the
Indiana State Board of Health but unfortunately, the Mayo Clinic Library
had neither this bulletin or your book. I was anxious to make extensive
notes and get photostatic copies not only of your chapter 28 but also of two
or three other items in your book. Mr. Ray Sweeney called my attention to the
photograph of the room in which Walter Reed read his paper. I am most anxious
to ask your permission to reproduce this photograph and would be delighted to
give credit to you if you would let me reproduce it in my book. Do you have
any sort of a print of this photograph, preferably a glossy print or best of
all, the negative? If so, would you lend it to me and I shall be glad to de-
fray whatever expense is concerned and will return it to you by insured post.
If you do not have the film or a photograph, do you have a cut which I might
borrow? I believe Mr. Sweeney thought that you did.

I expect to visit Cuba again the end of this month. The Cuban Govern-
ment has made Camp Lazear and the little building thereon a national monument
but has done nothing to preserve the little building and I am going to see what
can be done about this.

Do you have any idea how we could find out where Reed stayed in
Indianapolis in October 1900? I discussed this with Mr. Keeling but so far
we have no clue. Mr. Keeling thought he might have stayed at the Claypool

American Public Health Association in 1900 and who might have attended the
meeting. Perhaps I can get help from then also.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
